posts.author: CBS Dallas / Fort Worth
posts.title: Weekend Christmas Events Across North Texas
posts.text:
Follow KRLD: Facebook | Twitter 
NOTE: North Texas is expecting rain and chilly temperatures through the weekend. If you are planning to attend one of the area’s outdoor activities, you might want to check that event’s website before you leave the house. Plenty of events will likely see delays or cancellations due to inclement weather. 
The DFW Tamale Festival and Christmas Market is this Saturday at Dallas Farmers Market. (12/3) They’ll have local vendors, seasonal drinks, a kid zone, delicious tamales, carolers, and get your picture taken with Santa! Oh yeah…it is free! 
The Highland Park Christmas Tree Lighting Ceremony at Highland Park’s Big Pecan Tree is tonight. (12/2)At 6:00 PM, come enjoy a live reindeer, face painting, Christmas treats, a photobus, and a special North Pole mailbox to get letters to Santa quickly. 
The Magic of Christmas Light Show Spectacular in Grapevine is December 2 through January 8. 
Prairie Lights at Lynn Creek Park is Friday December 2 through January 1. 4 million lights set along 2 miles of path. Hundreds of ALL-NEW displays in shapes of all kinds line and arch over the roads. Half way through the drive get out of your car for a stop at Holiday Village where you will find food, gifts, Santa, the all-new indoor laser show, and the Holiday Magic Lighted Walk-Through Forest. Once back in your vehicle, the second half of the drive ends with the very animated light tunnel – the perfect finale to a night you will never forget! 
The Farmer’s Branch Tour of Lights is Friday December 2 through December 30 at Farmers Branch Historical Park. Millions of twinkling, festive lights beckon thousands of visitors throughout the season to come to the Farmers Branch Christmas Tour of Lights, now through December 30. 
The Denton Holiday Lighting Festival is Friday at Denton Courthouse Square. (12/2) 
The Allen Christmas Tree Lighting is Friday December 2 at Allen Civic Plaza. 
The Gift of Lights at Texas Motor Speedway is Friday December 2 through December 30. Check out the two-mile drive of light displays throughout the speedway. This year’s “Gift of Lights” is bigger and better than ever. During the drive, guests will enjoy more than 150 new light displays and more than a million more LED lights than last year, bringing the total of LED lights to three million. 
Check out the Vitruvian Lights Display this weekend through January 1st at Vitruvian Park. Millions of sparkling LED Lights are wrapped around more than 550 trees. 
The Arlington Holiday Lights Parade is Saturday December 3 in Downtown Arlington. 
The Twinkle Light Boat Parade is Saturday December 3 at Twin Coves Marina. 6 p.m. – 9 p.m. If you’re looking for a different sort of Christmas parade to float your boat, make your way to the Twinkle Light Boat Parade. You will find water crafts decorated in all of the finest sparkling lights to celebrate the season. This floating festival begins at Twin Coves Marina and picks up entries at each marina including Scott’s Landing and Silver Lake. The parade is visible from the shores of Lake Grapevine. This event is free. 
The 44th Annual Richardson Christmas Parade is Saturday December 3 at Richardson Square Mall. The parade will begin at 9:00 AM and will travel north from Richardson Square shopping center. 
The 47th Annual Rockwall Christmas Parade is Saturday December 3 at Rockwall Downtown Square. Lane Yudizky, a Pullen 4th grader, won the Rockwall Christmas parade poster contest. In addition to having his artwork used to promote the 47th annual Rockwall Kiwanis Christmas Parade, Lane will also serve as Parade Grand Marshall. 
DeSoto’s Hometown Holiday Parade is Saturday December 3 at Desoto Town Center. 
Klyde Warren Park’s Holiday Celebration is Saturday. (12/3) Free photos with Santa, face painting and kids holiday crafts throughout the day. Then stay for our new holiday show at 5:45 p.m., culminating in the tree lighting at 6 p.m. 
Experience Christmas at the White House tomorrow through January 8 at the George Bush Presidential Library . 
The Holiday Elegance Holiday Home Tour is Friday through Sunday at Dallas Women’s Forum. (12/2-4) at the Historic Alexander Mansion. Alexander Mansion is one of only two remaining mansions on Ross Avenue built at the turn of the 20th century

thread.title: Yep, it's true: Facebook is working on a competitor to Snapchat Discover
thread.title_full: Yep, it's true: Facebook is working on a competitor to Snapchat Discover

posts.author: Kerry Flynn and Jason Abbruzzese
posts.title: Yep, it's true: Facebook is working on a competitor to Snapchat Discover
posts.text:
Facebook is coming for Snapchat—specifically, Snapchat Discover, according to a Business Insider report published Friday, and a source who spoke to Mashable earlier today.
Mashable independently confirmed the existence of the the feature, called Collections, via a source familiar with the program's existence. The social network is reportedly asking publishers to create more content for them within a new feature called Collections. Sound familiar? 
SEE ALSO: Facebook to roomful of journalists: 'We hear you' 
The feature would include curated stories from individual publishers that would appear in Facebook's News Feed, according to potential Collections partners Business Insider spoke with, as well as documentation of the program reviewed by the reporter. 
At face-value, Collections sounds a lot like Twitter's Moments and, of course, Snapchat's Discover . In October 2015, Twitter released Moments to a handful of media outlets to curate collections of tweets. Now, anyone can create one. Discover is Snap's nearly two-year-old exclusive network of media and entertainment companies (of which Mashable is a partner). 
While Snapchat's offering is selective and thus limited in its choice of participants, it's been heralded by partners for its attentive audience of millions of daily users who provide another revenue source for publishers that wasn't there before. 
Facebook's roadmap 2016-2017: COPY.
— Wahid Razali (@WahidRazali) October 11, 2016 
Facebook has held talks with media outlets and entertainment companies over recent weeks about Collections, according to Business Insider, though no other timeframe for the new offering was reported.
Facebook did not immediately respond to Mashable 's request for comment. 
If the Business Insider report turns out to be completely accurate, it comes in an interesting moment. For one thing, Facebook finds itself continuously fending off criticism for both the way it won't call itself media company (despite so many publishers' fates now being inextricably linked to Facebook's users) as well as its role in spreading fake news . The company fired its own curation team for a section of the site called Trending Topics, following Gizmodo's report on the potential suppression of conservative news. 
Mashable will continue to update this story as it develops.

thread.section_title: ‘La La Land’ Named Best Film By New York Film Critics – CBS Miami
thread.title: ‘La La Land’ Named Best Film By New York Film Critics
thread.title_full: ‘La La Land’ Named Best Film By New York Film Critics

posts.author: cbs4maselli
posts.title: ‘La La Land’ Named Best Film By New York Film Critics
posts.text:
Follow CBSMIAMI.COM: Facebook | Twitter 
NEW YORK (AP) — Damien Chazelle’s Los Angeles musical “La La Land” was named best film of the year by the New York Film Critics Circle.
The group announced their picks Thursday on Twitter, spreading around their awards to a variety of Oscar contenders. The top award came as something of a twist after the critics’ early choices leaned toward Barry Jenkins’ coming-of-age portrait “Moonlight” and Kenneth Lonergan’s grief-filled drama “Manchester by the Sea.”
“Moonlight” won awards for best director (Jenkins), best cinematography (James Laxton) and best supporting actor (Mahershala Ali). “Manchester by the Sea” took best actor for Casey Affleck, best screenplay for Lonergan and best supporting actress for Michelle Williams. Williams was honored jointly for her performances in “Manchester by the Sea” and Kelly Reichardt’s “Certain Women.”
Best film was the sole award for “La La Land,” which opens next week. Chazelle’s film, starring Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling, also led the Critics’ Choice Awards nominations on Thursday with 12 nods.
Those three films — “La La Land,” ”Moonlight” and “Manchester by the Sea”— have been the favored critics’ choices in the early going of Hollywood’s awards season. “Moonlight” led the Gotham Film Independent Awards on Monday. “Manchester by the Sea” topped the National Board of Review Awards on Tuesday.
Each group, however, has its own quirks and other favorites — Denzel Washington’s “Fences” and Martin Scorsese’s late-arriving “Silence,” among others — are also in the mix. On Sunday, the Los Angeles Film Critics Association will make their picks.
The NYFCC, a body of several dozen New York-area critics, named Isabelle Huppert best actress for her lead performances in Paul Verhoeven’s “Elle” and Mia Hansen-Love’s “The Things to Come.” Best first-film was a tie between Kelly Fremon Craig’s teen comedy “The Edge of Seventeen” and Trey Edward Shults’ micro-budget family drama “Krisha.”
Special awards were also singled out for Thelma Schoonmaker, Scorsese’s longtime editor, and the 25th anniversary restoration of Julie Dash’s “Daughters of the Dust.”

thread.title: Did Trump Win Because Of Fake News On Facebook? Swedish Official To Take On Social Network For Spreading Hate Speech
thread.title_full: Did Trump Win Because Of Fake News On Facebook? Swedish Official To Take On Social Network For Spreading Hate Speech

posts.title: Did Trump Win Because Of Fake News On Facebook? Swedish Official To Take On Social Network For Spreading Hate Speech
posts.text:
12/02/16 AT 3:09 PM Close 
Days after a Swedish comedian sent Facebook co-founder and chief executive Mark Zuckerberg an open letter disparaging the social network’s allowances of hate speech and false news, the country’s culture minister told the local Expressen newspaper Thursday that she planned to invite the tech billionaire overseas to discuss the issues. 
“I am convinced that they do not want to be an arena for threats, hate and false news,” Alice Bah Kuhnke told the paper’s culture section. She added that the spread of hateful messaging and baseless stories on Facebook “has gone over the limit” and that if the Menlo Park, California-based company doesn’t make any changes, Sweden and its Nordic neighbors “are prepared to take the next step.” 
Jonas Gardell, a famed Swedish comedian and author who is openly gay, urged Zuckerberg to consider hiring an editor or publisher who “takes responsibility” for verifying false information propagated on the social network, and pointed to the presidential election victory of Donald Trump as a consequence of Facebook’s present lack of an editorial filter. Gardell called Trump “godless” and told Zuckerberg he should be “ashamed of the lies” the social network allowed to spread in the months leading up to the election. Related Stories China Urges Stricter Internet Restrictions To Curb Fake News Surge 
According to Facebook’s Help Center , the social network defines hate speech as “content that attacks people based on their actual or perceived race, ethnicity, national origin, religion, sex, gender identity, sexual orientation, disability or disease,” and makes exceptions for jokes considered to be “a possible threat or attack” or simply “in bad taste.” Facebook pledges to remove content and accounts that pose physical safety risks, according to its Community Standards page , and offers directions for reporting abuse . 
As for the issue of false information, Facebook followed Google Inc.’s lead in mid-November when the social network updated its Audience Network policy to specifically ban the display or integration of “fake news” in its apps or websites. 
The debate over social networks’ role in the spread of hate speech and misinformation paraded as facts has gained steam in the wake of the Nov. 8 election, as many— even Facebook executives themselves — pointed to the social network as a generous platform for false stories that may have influenced the way Americans voted. 
Facebook did not respond to inquiries from International Business Times by press time. Join the Discussion Everything You Need To Know, Right Now.

thread.title_full: Who monitors the news? | GulfNews.com

posts.author: Sanya Nayeem, Deputy Readers Editor
posts.title: Who monitors the news?
posts.text:
A majority eight of ten Gulf News poll respondents think social media networks like Facebook should take responsibility for moderating fake news.
Since the US elections, Mark Zuckerberg has been under attack, based on conjecture that false information - mostly pro-Donald Trump - presented as news and circulated on Facebook may have tipped the election’s outcome.
Now, Facebook will likely make several changes, enabling users to report false information more easily. There is also speculation they might invite third parties to add warnings to stories that appear suspect, or hire editors to monitor content.
However, the perception that Facebook might become responsible for policing the “truth” gives the network a lot of editorial power - something many social media users are not comfortable with.
What do you think is the best solution?

thread.title: Can you see who views your Facebook profile? Here's what you need to know. | Mic
thread.title_full: Can you see who views your Facebook profile? Here's what you need to know. | Mic

posts.title: Can you see who views your Facebook profile? Here's what you need to know. | Mic
posts.text: TWEET Have you recently developed a crush? Connected with an old classmate? Accepted your boss' friend request? For better or worse, it could be useful to see who is visiting your profile. Does Facebook offer a way to see who's viewed your profile or posts? Despite the rumors you may have heard over the years, the answer is a resounding no. The concept of Facebook profile views is a pure myth. The Facebook Help Center states : No. Facebook doesn't let you track who views your profile or your posts (ex: your photos.) Third-party apps are also unable to do this. If you come across an app that says it can show you who's viewing your profile or posts, please report the app. Note Facebook's emphasis on third-party apps: Chances are you've encountered a website or mobile app boldly claiming its service allows you to "See who views your profile!" Not only are those third-party clients lying, but they could be collecting your personal information or infecting your device with malware . Whatever their intention, all of these apps are scams. For more info, check out Facebook's data policy . Like us on Facebook:

thread.title: How to Stop Facebook Videos from Auto-Playing
thread.title_full: How to Stop Facebook Videos from Auto-Playing

posts.author: Jason Fitzpatrick
posts.title: How to Stop Facebook Videos from Auto-Playing
posts.text:
How to Stop Facebook Videos from Auto-Playing 
Remember the days when Facebook videos only played when you clicked on them? If you want to return to that far finer age, all you need to do is toggle a few tucked-away settings to stop the auto-play madness. 
Auto-playing videos are annoying at best (maybe you didn’t want that video to start playing in front of everyone in sight of your screen) and data-wasting at worst (maybe you didn’t want to burn up that data on a video you didn’t even really want to watch)—so we totally understand if you want to put an end to it. Let’s start with Facebook’s mobile apps and then move onto the desktop for total coverage. How to Disable Auto-Play on Mobile Devices 
To disable auto-playing video on Facebook’s mobile applications, we need to head over to the settings menu. We’re using iOS for this tutorial, but the option is the same on both iOS and Android. Select the menu icon to access your settings. 
Select “Settings” in the resulting menu. 
Select “Account Settings” in the pop up menu. 
Select “Videos and Photos” from the Account Settings menu. 
Within the “Videos and Photos” menu select “Autoplay”. 
There you can toggle the settings between always playing regardless of the network, only auto-playing on Wi-Fi, and never. Select “Never Autoplay Videos”. How to Disable Auto-Play on the Desktop 
No need to stop our war there—let’s spend an extra few seconds to do away with it on the desktop too. Log into your Facebook account and click on the menu arrow in the upper right corner. Select “Settings”. 
Within the settings menu, select “Videos” from the bottom of the left hand navigation pane. 
Within the “Video Settings” menu, select the drop down box beside “Auto-Play Videos” and toggle it to “Off”. 
With that quick change, auto-playing videos are now a thing of the past.

thread.title: Snapchat Discover, Meet Facebook Collections? | SocialTimes
thread.title_full: Snapchat Discover, Meet Facebook Collections? | SocialTimes

posts.author: David Cohen
posts.title: Snapchat Discover, Meet Facebook Collections? | SocialTimes
posts.text:
Next up on the list of Snapchat features cloned by Facebook is Collections, the social network’s take on Snapchat Discover .
Alex Heath of Business Insider reported that Collections, much like Snapchat Discover, will bring news, listicles, videos and other content curated by media partners to Facebook’s News Feed .
Heath cited two people familiar with the project, as well as internal Facebook documentation, and he reported that Facebook has engaged in talks with media and entertainment companies about content for Collections, but there has been no word on when it plans to launch the feature.
According to Heath, the potential Collections partners have been told that their content will go directly into News Feed, and there was no indication whether advertising would be part of the mix and, if so, under what terms.
The Collections feature Heath reported on should not be confused with a previous Facebook feature with the same name.
The social network began testing a feature called Collections in October 2012 , in which select retailers were able to add “collect” and “want” options and buy links to images of products. That initial test was shelved later that month .
Facebook once again tested Collections in December of that year with a mix of some of the retailers from the first test and some new partners, but the social network announced that it was shelving the feature in February 2014.
Readers: What are your thoughts on the Collections feature Facebook is reportedly working on?
Image courtesy of Shutterstock .

thread.title: Man mocked in heroin OD video says it's 'best thing that...
thread.title_full: Man mocked in heroin OD video says it's 'best thing that...

posts.author: palmbeachpost.com
posts.title: Man mocked in heroin OD video says it's 'best thing that...
posts.text:
MEMPHIS It took 46 years to get to this point. Live on Facebook, passed out from a drug overdose.
Ronald Hiers was trying to kill himself.
He has been battling addiction for almost 50 years. His poison of choice has evolved throughout the years.
It was alcohol in high school, cocaine in his 20s and 30s, and ended with heroin.
>> Read more trending stories
One of his wake up calls came when a disturbing video showing Hiers and his wife passed out on the sidewalk was posted online.
People walked by him as if he weren't a human being. They poked at him, laughed and didn't call 911.
“That video was the best thing that happened to me. It got me here, and here is where I’ve been trying to get to 46 years,” Hiers said.
After he watched the video again, he said it doesn't get any less painful. But, he has no resentment for the man who posted it.
“He didn't owe me a phone call. He didn't owe me anything. He didn't get me there. He didn't get my wife there. She and I got ourselves there,” Hiers said.
Now, the Frayser High School graduate faces his demons at Turning Point , an addiction-recovery center in Southaven, Miss.
It’s a battle he is doing alone, not with his wife..
Turning Point said that if a family or couple has a history of using together, it is best they are treated separately.
When couples go through intentional separation in treatment, a critical turning point has to happen. It is an internal change that grounds them to further the work needed to maintain long-term sustainable recovery.
The road has not been easy, but Hiers has not lost his faith.
“That's what God does. He puts you in the path of things he wants you to see and guess he got tired of me not calling him, he had to call me,” Hiers said.
God wasn’t the only one he said called. On the top of his list to thank is his daughter.
“She made it possible. She bothered me on my telephone for hours that day,” Hiers said. “I didn't want to talk to her. I'm busy trying to kill myself, but she kept calling.”
If he meets the man who posted the video, he wants to ask one question: "Would you have called 911 if it had been one of (your) loved ones?”

thread.title: How to Make a Gourd Birdhouse (Because, Baby, it’s Cold Outside)
thread.title_full: How to Make a Gourd Birdhouse (Because, Baby, it’s Cold Outside)

posts.author: Chris Hull
posts.title: How to Make a Gourd Birdhouse (Because, Baby, it’s Cold Outside)
posts.text:
Share on Facebook iStock/Xuntes 
Is it getting cold in your neighborhood? You’re not the only one feeling winter’s chill. Many varieties of birds are losing their natural habitats and need a dry, safe place to shelter during the colder months. You can help the birds by making a gourd birdhouse; it’s a fun DIY project that kids will enjoy helping with as well. Materials: 
drill with a 2″ diameter doorknob hole cutter 1/4″ drill bit sand paper or wire brush bleach exterior latex paint or oil based primer and enamel paint leather shoe lace How to make a gourd birdhouse: 
Step 1: It’s easiest to buy a dried gourd. But, if you can’t find one, then dry a fresh gourd by storing it in a cool, dry place for 3-6 months. You’ll know it’s dry when you shake it and hear the seeds rattle inside. 
Step 2: Drill a 2″ hole in the front of the gourd. This will be the door to the birdhouse. 
Step 3: Use the knife and/or spoon to scoop out the insides of the gourd. 
Step 4: Use the sand paper or wire brush to sand the exterior of the gourd smooth. This will help the paint to stick. Pay special attention to the edges of the hole so that the birds can enter and exit safely. 
Step 5: Mix a 1:10 solution of bleach and water and soak the gourd for 15 minutes to sanitize it. Then rinse in clean water and allow it to air dry. Be sure to protect yourself by wearing rubber gloves and eye protection while working with the bleach solution. 
Step 6: Paint the exterior of the gourd to protect it. Have fun with this step and get creative with your painting. 
Step 7: Drill three small drainage holes in the bottom of the birdhouse with the 1/4″ drill bit. Drill another two holes in the top to thread the leather lace through to hang. Who’ll be stopping by? 
Purple martins will definitely be attracted to your gourd birdhouse. This is good news because they’re great at controlling insect populations. Don’t be surprised if you also see bluebirds, swallows, chickadees, wrens, woodpeckers, titmice, great crested flycatchers, screech owls, kestrels, and nuthatches. Why it’s (really) important 
Many birds are environmental refugees. They lose more and more of their habitat to development, agriculture, and forestry each year. By providing them a safe, dry home you’re encouraging them to mate and stay nearby to raise their young. 
According to the United States Fish and Wildlife Service , “Loss, degradation and fragmentation of important migratory bird habitat have been identified as potentially the largest individual threat to migratory birds. Much of this is human caused by development. Birds need essential resources for breeding, feeding, shelter, and survival, including access to food, water, and nesting sites.” 
Rare, endangered species aren’t the only birds threatened. Many birds that are much more commonplace are under threat as well. According to National Geographic , “A National Audubon Society report…shows that some widespread species generally thought to be secure have decreased in number as much as 80 percent since 1967, and the 19 others in the report have lost half their populations.”

posts.text:
08:18 am 
Asking both here and on Facebook. Flaming Crab is currently working on a follow-up to our original "Letters from the Flaming Crab: Culinary Magic" entitled "The Culinary Magic Cookbook". The original introduced culinary magic as a form of hedge magic (one anyone can do if they have a specific feat but that requires a successful skill check to perform). It included roughly fifteen recipes as well as a set of feats and traits to go with it. There were also two archetypes: the performing chef (bard) and the kitchen witch (witch). 
So, as we expand the book to include at least 70 recipes and a few new archetypes, my question to the Pathfinder public: 
What do you want in your cooking magic? Besides cupcakes, BJ Hensley. :) What would you like to see which would help convince you to buy this book? This is your chance to help shape a product before it hits production. Please comment and let us know.
